div.head: Section 6
div.p: Nevertheless for a greater declaration and solution of this object some considerations should be put forward.

The first consideration is that since the domnions and jurisdictions, status and royal dignities are belong to infidels by the law of nations (ius gentium) and natural law, and have been confirmed by both divine law and especially evangelical law, it is manifest that the catholic faith or the Christian religion do not deprive infidel kings or lords from their status, dignities, and goods or other rights and dominion which they have over their subjects by natural law and the law of the people, but on the contrary the faith justifies these rights.

And that they have been approved by divine law is clear from the old law in which it is mentioned a thousand times about infidel and idolatrous kings. Of the first king Nimrod, in Genesis 10: the beginning of his kingdom was Babylon. And also the four kings of Sodom and Gomorrah in Genesis 14. And the thirty kings of Canaan, in the book of Numbers. And throughout nearly all books of divine scripture there is frequent memory of idolatrous kings. And, while not mentioning many other things, Nebuchadnezzar is called king by the divine mouth itself: Behold, he says, I will bring against Tyre Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon from the north, king of kings, with horses etc. And to this Daniel said, not for the sake of flattery but in order to reveal the truth,
you are the king of kings and the God of heaven gave to the kingdom and fortitude and empyreum and glory
etc Daniel 2. From this therefore God his own scriptures calls kings those who are infidels and even idolatrous kings. They are kings
because he himself said it and it was done . Psalm 148

And the patriarchs and prophets also showed reverence and obedience to the infidel, idolatrous, and wicked kings under whose rule they lived, as saint Joseph did to Pharaoh, Daniel to Nebuchadnezzar, Mordecai and Esther to Ahasuerus, and in Baruch chapter 1, it is said,
Pray for the life of Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and for the life of Belshazzar, his son, that their days may be like the days of heaven on earth, so that we may live under the shadow of Nebuchadnezzar and the shadow of Belshazzar, his son, and serve them for many days etc.

The Prophetic King David also honored Saul after God had withdrawn from him because he was still the king and was so as long as he lived. Thus Augustine says in his questions on the old and new testament, question 35,
For what reason did David call Saul the anointed of the Lord and give honor to him after God had left him. David was not unaware that the divine tradition is in the office of the royal order. Therefore he honored Saul in this same tradition, lest he would seem to do injury to God, who had decreed that there should be honor for these orders. For the king has the image of God, just as the bishop bears the image of Christ, therefore as long as he is in this tradition the king should be honored, even if not for his own sake or on account of the order. Thus the apostle says in Romans 13.
Be subject to the higher authorities, for there is no power unless it is from God. For those powers that exist are from God . this is the reason why when a gentile is in power we still honor them, even though they are unworthy and, while holding God's office, are actually serving the devil. For power demands honor because it deserves honor. For thus a future famine was revealed in a dream to the pharoah, and Nabechadnezzar along among those assisting him saw the son of God in the furnace, not because he had his own merit, for he wanted to be worshipped in his own idol, but through the merit of the royal order. This is what Augustine says in the text.

¶ Behold how infidel, idolatrous, and most wicked kings have kingdom, empire, strength and glory, that is, the excellence of dignity and the royal order from the God of heaven, and are in the tradition, that is, in the royal office constituted by God, although infidels, and therefore merit honor and reverence, bearing the image of God. Hence it appears that the aforesaid dignities and royal states, domains and jurisdictions, were introduced by natural and common law, confirmed by the divine law of the Old Testament.

¶ That they are approved and confirmed by the evangelical law, there are innumerable authorities. And the first is thus, this of the very author of justice, Christ:
Matthew 22
,
Render to Caesar the things that are Caesar's
, etc. By which words he taught that tribute and royal rights should be rendered to Caesar, an ethnic infidel, and in him to all other ethnic idolaters and infidels. Render, he says, not give, because to render signifies payment; but payment presupposes a debt. For tribute is owed even to infidel kings by the obligation of natural justice, as is clear in Romans where above:
Render to all their dues: tribute to whom tribute is due, custom to whom custom, honor to whom honor
, etc. For the Apostle was speaking of infidel princes, with whom the world was then full,
whom nevertheless he calls ministers of God serving in this very thing.
Therefore by necessity be subject
.

The solicitous apostles strove to promulgate this same thing to all the faithful and first Christians, commanding that they observe obedience and honor and rights to infidel princes as one of the divine precepts of the evangelical law. 1 Timothy 6:
Whosoever are under the yoke (interlinear gloss:
of infidels
, servants), let us deem their masters worthy of all honor, lest the name of the Lord be blasphemed. But those who have faithful masters, let them not despise them, but rather serve them, because they are faithful
. And to Titus 3:
Admonish them to be subject to princes and powers, to obey commands, to be ready for every good work
, etc.

¶ Having your conversation, that is, exterior acts and works, good among the gentiles (that is, living among gentiles and infidels, so that you may provoke them to faith according to Saint Thomas), so that in that which they speak against you as evildoers— because through the indiscretion and pride of some of those already converted to the faith, after receiving the faith they said that the faithful were not bound to obey infidel princes— therefore infidel lords complained and blasphemed the faith as unjust, because it removed the rights of nature and the condition or order of human condition as if unjust and evildoers. And it follows: from good works, that is, from the due obedience and showing of subjection (by which you were bound to your lords before your conversion), considering you, they may glorify God in the day of visitation, that is, of calling or of your conversion or theirs. And blessed Peter immediately infers the conclusion which he intended:
Be subject therefore to every human creature
(the gloss and Saint Thomas there:
to faithful and unbelievers
). These things that one and the other. And it is an accommodated distribution for those under whose power they were, for God's sake, that is, with God so ordaining:
whether to the king as supreme, or to governors
, because this is the will of God, that by doing well, that is, by thus obeying, you may make silent, withdrawing from them the material of complaining and blaspheming, the ignorance of imprudent men, that is, of infidels. And shortly after:
Fear God, honor the king. Servants be subject in all fear, not only to the good and modest, but to the harsh, that is, to infidels
.

¶ Likewise
Paul in 1 Timothy 6
commanded that
supplications, prayers, thanksgivings be made for kings and all who are, or were, constituted in high position, that we may lead a quiet and tranquil life
.

For it is manifest that at the time when the Apostles promulgated these precepts to the faithful and first Christians, the whole world (as we said)
was full of infidel princes or kings, and no king or prince was faithful. Therefore the dignities and royal states, domains and jurisdictions, and royal rights which are among infidels were and are approved and confirmed by the divine law of the New Testament, or by the evangelical law.

¶ But that the faith of Christ and the Christian religion do not deprive infidel kings or princes of their domains, states and dignities, jurisdictions and rights, etc., which pertain to kings and the authority and excellence of kings, is already clear from what has been adduced. Because if God through the divine law of the Old Testament, and again through the new evangelical law, confirmed and established all the aforesaid, therefore it would be blasphemous to think that he would have revoked them through the faith, and much less the infidels themselves by receiving the faith.

¶ But let us add other particular reasons and authorities. And the first is this: The order of superiority by which men are subject to their princes is an order of natural justice instituted by God, according to Romans 13:
There is no power except from God; but those things which are from God, he resists the ordination
. And he speaks of the order by which inferiors are subdued to their superiors. But the faith of Christ is the principle and cause of justice, according to Romans 3:
The justice of God through faith in Jesus Christ, unto all and upon all who believe in him
. Therefore through the faith of Christ the order of justice is not removed, but rather confirmed. But the order of justice requires that inferiors obey their superiors, whether they be faithful or infidels, because justice extends not only to the faithful but also to all men universally. Therefore infidel princes, or even their subjects, especially by receiving the faith, do not lose their domains, jurisdictions, dignities, and rights owed. For this would be to be of better condition in their infidelity than existing in Christianity and in the holy Church, contrary to what is held in
c. iudei. el. 2o, extra, de iudeis et sarracenis
, where it is commanded under penalty of excommunication that for Jews coming to the faith,
their possessions should not be taken away, since those converted to the faith ought to be of better condition than they were held before they received the faith
. These things there.

¶ The same and more is contained in a certain extravagant of John 22, subtitle concerning Jews in the community. Judging it worthy, he says, and consonant with law that those reborn from the font of baptism, with Jewish blindness dismissed, should abound in more ample favors or graces than before, it is indecent and absurd that those who abounded in perfidy should be compelled to beg as faithful. And below: We strictly command and mandate that to such converted ones and those who will be converted in the future, in their possessions and other goods, by whatever name they may be called, which they held at the time of conversion or even will hold, no molestation should be inflicted on account of the aforesaid occasion, nor should they permit it to be inflicted by others, but showing themselves favorable to them in these and other things, they should protect and defend them from injuries and molestations, so that thus they may perceive that they have passed from servitude to freedom, nor should they be compelled by the pretext of hateful mendicity to return to the dismissed perfidy. These things there. For indeed, in truth, a great disgrace would be done to the Catholic faith, since the Christian religion would be esteemed as unjust and tyrannical and would be held in hatred, and consequently we would provide material for blaspheming Christ the Lord, the bearer of the evangelical law, if we should attempt the contrary of the aforesaid, as is manifest.

¶ The second reason: If through this faith the grace of the Holy Spirit is given, which is principally called the evangelical law itself, but grace does not remove nature but perfects and supplies the defect of nature, according to
Saint Thomas 1st part q. 2 article 6 ad 1
and
2-2 q. 188 article 8
, but principalities and powers, domains and jurisdictions which are among infidels of whatever nation, sect, or religion they exist (except however the Jews after the death of Christ), pertain to those by natural and common law, which laws the evangelical divine law and the grace of the Holy Spirit has restored, augmented, confirmed according to Augustine, perfected and supplied according to Saint Thomas. Therefore infidels, especially by receiving the faith, do not lose their principalities, dignities, powers, etc., but rather are confirmed and participate in them.

¶ Third, it is proven by authorities.
And first Augustine on John 18, expounding that word
My kingdom is not of this world
:
Hear, he says, therefore, Jews and gentiles; hear, circumcision; hear, foreskin; hear, all kingdoms of the earth: I do not impede your dominion in this world; my kingdom is not of this world. Do not fear with most vain fear by which that greater Herod, when it was announced that Christ was born, was frightened and killed so many infants that death might reach him, fearing and becoming more cruel by anger.
My kingdom, he says, is not of this world
. What more do you want? Come to the kingdom which is not of this world; come by believing and do not rage by fearing
, etc.

¶ And on that Psalm 118:
Princes have persecuted me without cause
, sermon 31, the same Augustine:
For what harm had Christians done to earthly kingdoms,
although their king promised them the kingdoms of heaven? What harm, I say, had they done to earthly kingdoms?
Never did their king prohibit his soldiers from paying and showing what is owed to kings of the earth. Did he not say to the Jews who were contriving calumny against him:
Render to Caesar the things that are Caesar's and to God the things that are God's
? Did he not himself even pay tribute from the mouth of a fish? Did not his precursor, to soldiers of this kingdom asking what they should do for eternal salvation, say:
Loose your belt, throw down your arms, desert your king, that you may be able to serve God
? But he said:
Shake down no one, make false accusation to no one, let your wages suffice you
. Did not one of his soldiers and his most beloved comrade say to his fellow soldiers and in the manner of Christ to his provincials:
Let every soul be subject to the higher powers
? And a little after he says:
Render to all their dues: tribute to whom tribute, custom to whom custom, fear to whom fear, honor to whom honor. Owe no one anything except to love one another
. Did he not command that the church should pray even for those kings? What therefore did Christians offend them? That they did not render what was due? In what did Christians not obey earthly kings? Therefore earthly kings persecuted Christians without cause
, etc. These things Augustine. Behold how Augustine passes sentence against those things which in our times have been perpetrated by Christians concerning infidels, especially the Indian nations, concerning which ours will by no means boast,
because not without cause but most deservedly, if strength should supply them, they would persecute them.

¶ Chrysostom also on the aforesaid word:
Every soul
, etc., homily 23: Of this thing, he says, he makes mention very much also in other epistles,
just as he subjects servants to their masters, so also subjects to their princes. But he does this therefore that he may show that Christ introduced his laws not to overturn polities, but to institute them for the better, and at the same time to teach that superfluous and useless wars are not to be undertaken
. And below:
And he does not simply say: obey, but be subject. But there is the first justice of this constitution which is both sufficient and decorous and honest to faithful thoughts and members, namely that these things are ordained by God
. And far below the same Chrysostom says:
For if Paul commanded these things when the princes were still gentiles, much more ought they to be shown to the faithful
, etc. These things Chrysostom.

¶ The authority of the universal Church confirms the aforeshown, which on the feast of Epiphany sings, reproving King Herod, saying:
O impious enemy Herod, why do you fear that Christ is coming? He does not take away mortal kingdoms, who gives celestial kingdoms
.

¶ Behold how manifestly it is shown by authorities and reasons, beyond very many others which we have more fully adduced elsewhere, that the law of Christ not only does not remove from infidel princes their dignities and kingdoms or their royal rights, but rather confirms and establishes them, since the contrary would be to overturn the republics and the order which he himself established with the Father and the Holy Spirit, which Saint Thomas on 1 Corinthians chapter 6 did not pass over in silence, saying that it is
against divine law to impede subjects, even Christians, from appearing whenever they have been called before infidel princes or judges
. These things from him.

¶ But if the aforealleged things do not suffice, let the decree and declaration of the Apostolic See itself finally suffice, through
Pope Paul III, who in his bull beginning
Sublimis Deus so loved the human race
, where he concludes by decreeing and declaring:
that our Indians and all other peoples who may come to the knowledge of Christians in the future, although they exist outside the faith of Christ, are nevertheless not deprived or to be deprived of their liberty or of the dominion of their things; indeed they can use, possess, and enjoy freely and licitly this kind of liberty and dominion, nor ought they to be reduced into servitude, and that whatever may happen to be done otherwise is irritated and void, of no strength or moment,
and that the same Indians and other peoples are to be invited to the said faith of Christ by the preaching of the word and the example of good life, we decree and declare by apostolic authority through the present letters
, etc. These things there.

Therefore it is clear that infidels justly possess kingdoms and principalities and domains and jurisdictions, not only over infidel subjects but even over the faithful, if it happens that by some right or some reason they are subject to them, and consequently infidel kings or princes, especially those receiving the Catholic faith, do not lose their kingdoms, principalities, and other royal rights.
